answers.author: Tom Nosack
answers.text:
At the risk of stepping on toes and pride in very well presented budgets, I have discovered over the last decade or so that the holy grail matchup of performance measures to budget means very different things to different people. 
For some "budget centrists" the ideal seems to be more of a technical approach that matches a set of fixed program level measures that drive budget decisions to each program. Changes in budget "semi-automatically" based on specific changes in performance.  It minimizes the managers’ role, simplifying the process significantly. It can be displayed fairly completely in the budget document.
For “performance folks” it seems to be a set of flexible, multi-level measures that tell the story about what is happening in service delivery and cost within the organization. This information is used for discussion that informs the budget process.  It is less well defined and “messier” than the technical approach. It reinforces the managers’ role in the budget process but requires them to be more informed and articulate about their business. It can’t all be displayed in a set of charts and narratives.
I tend to believe in the “performance folks” view as closer to where we need to land. Performance information is essential to the budget process outside of government and should be inside, too. We are not there – yet.
Tom

answers.author: Barry Crook
answers.text:
John -- I think what you do is to use the performance metrics to raise these questions of cause-and-effect. If the money is being spent and not achieving what was intended, you want to know "Why?" It could be the baseline assumption about causality is incorrect. It might be that the result is delayed by time and other things intervene. It might be that you are not spending enough money, or spending it on the wrong thing, or the problem you thought you had is not the problem at all, or the work processes being used to attack the problem needs improving/changing. The use of metrics usually leads to more questions, that make you think about the problem at hand . . . and lead to better "fixes."
My own experience with performance metrics, budgets and elected officials is that they don't pay enough attention to the metrics if it doesn't support their viewpoint on the program/service in question and use it if it does . . . in fact, I had one elected official tell me just that on one occasion: "Barry, I love these measures you bring us and will us it when it supports my position, thanks."

answers.author: John Garvison
answers.text:
Tom: You hit the concerns that I have squarely on the head. My question is, do we use the idea of 'performance budgeting' to justify the projects that we are in favor of, and give short shrift to the projects we are not in favor of, and utilize performance budgeting to do so? Don't get me wrong, I am in favor of using performance budgeting and the former Governor of the State of Washington, Gary Locke used it in preparing the State's budgets, and he did an pretty good job of utilizing it.
It was called Priorities of Government, and it actually upset many apple carts at multiple state agencies, because the performance measures did not support many 'pet' projects that legislators or agency department directors wanted to do.
So, the question I am wondering is, do we use performance budgeting and the use of metrics to determine if the dollars we allocated to a specific project were actually useful? Also, are the metrics easily understood for our citizens, staff, elected officials, and partners?
Those are the questions I would love to see answered, because that is the question our elected officials need to have answered.

answers.author: Tom Nosack
answers.text:
Now you are seeing my point.
John, we just finished a “priorities of government” type process in Vancouver that took us close to a year. We used some existing and generated on-the-fly performance measures more and better than we ever have, but have lots of room to improve and it still isn’t where it needs to be by a long shot.
 When introducing performance measures into a budget process, the traditional way is for budget staff to request measures from everybody, usually following a specific format to be included in the document. 
That is where analysis ends, and in my mind and so does most usefulness.  It isn’t because of a lack of good intentions or talented people, there are plenty of these. It is mode because they are “generating numbers” to mark the block that says include the performance measures in the budget document.  The measures are rarely generated to answer a specific question or initiate a performance/value discussion.
These are some of the questions we should be asking the performance measures to answer – otherwise don’t include them! How often have you seen any of them answered:
How is the program actually doing? What are they providing that is valued? What does it cost? How good is the quality? Does it meet the standards of our customers? Are we providing it the best way possible to meet the need? We never seem to ask these questions – because they are often the hardest to answer or we don’t want to hear the answer. (to Barry’s point)
Tom

answers.author: Roderick Wood
answers.text:
Some excellent points by everyone. ICMA has been struggling to develop generic and meaningful Performance Measures for 40 years that I know of.  I will assume everyne has a program based budget to indentigyf the services provided.  If you are not already, I would suggest you start with a basic performance measure of what service are we getting for the money allocated.  The public likes this kind of information.  It can be that residential trash is picked up once a week and it costs $x dollars for residential service or $y per household.  Now they know the level of service and the costs of that service on a unit costs basis.  It gives a budget a means to show the affect on service of a budget change up or down.  You can also provide service unit costs for each program.  In police work, it is the officer that provides direct service.  The sargents and above are support to the officer.  (Yes I recognize that sargents do get into responses, but their primary purpose is supervision of the officer and activity.)  If you divide the number of police officers by the total police budget including all charge backs like facilties and vehicle manintnce shop, computers etc, you have what it costs to put a police officer on the street and what you save to take one off.   Of course you have to mindful of the differentials in marginal costs versus averaging costs.

answers.author: Roderick Wood
answers.text:
One additional point, one of the things I have include in the budget and costs to each program as applicable is the what I call the "costs of governance".  This is the costs of democracy.  What are we doing such as a Planning Commission and all the processes that go with it that the private sector does not have to do?  We are compared to the private sector for efficiency and overhead costs which is not a fair comparison.  Government is obligated to processes in the public interest that should not be included in the base costs analysis of providing the actual service. These should be listed as a separate overhead.  It gives a much more accurate and honest unit costs of providing the actual service.  This is especially appropriate if you require Departments to competitively bid work against the private sector.  I do not believe the costs of governance should be included in the bid price as it is a costs regardless of who provides the service.  You can check the Beverly Hills budget on line to see how this process was done.  Like all budget information, it is a work in progress.

answers.author: Tom Nosack
answers.text:
The concept of any piece of government being “exempt” from scrutiny would be a difficult swallow for our community, but I understand where you are coming from.  Our verbal Vancouverites might say to us “...And private sector has R&D requirements...competition that drives pricing...market restrictions.. shareholder management..advertising.. “  so those would offset our expenses for “cost of  governance” and make it a wash.
They might be right, too: we are finding every month that we can and should be acting more and more like a true business model.  Our staffing is shockingly low in nearly every area compared to other cities, but our results seem pretty reasonable. We are finding we can have finance as a percent of revenue be competitive with the outside world (< 1.5% of operating expenses)..HR can be pretty bare bones...etc. and the citizens are overall satisfied enough that they are not willing to “buy more government”. Is that success?
Don't get me wrong: I agree that some of government needs to be called out separately but I think only a limited amount of it would be totally inappropriate to include (such as Council's salaries and support cost). 
Overhead that is allocated needs to be as transparent as possible so it can be dissected and opportunities found to do it better. We are doing better, but not there yet.
For competitive contracting we will probably do what you are initially – but in the second or third round we would want to start including more of those “cost of governance” pieces… just because it feels appropriate…

answers.author: Robert Cole
answers.text:
Coming late to the conversation, I can't add much to what Tom and Barry have already communicated. That written, one additional highlight is worth commenting on. I’ve noted that organizations first venturing into performance measurement often do so because elected officials and others want quantitative support for budget decision-making. While that is a perfectly rational basis for developing a performance measurement system, the real strength of these systems is in supporting organizational learning and strategic planning, of which resource allocation (budgeting) is but a component, though an important one. Fundamentally, performance measurement systems need employee buy-in and exercise to remain healthy, properly functioning feedback (learning) loops. 
By “exercise”, I mean they must be used by staff at all levels in the organization on a routine basis – not on a monthly, quarterly, or annual basis, but daily, as appropriate. All staff must know how their performance is assessed, have easy-access to indicators that help to self-assess progress in advancing personal, departmental, or organizational goals and objectives, and know how his/her activities influence important outcomes. Not everyone needs to be a statistics geek, but rather have access to meaningful feedback for his/her level of responsibility. For example, a building permit counter clerk may have access to day before customer service survey results from counter activity, among other insights. 
All too often, those aspiring to link performance measures to budget deliberations and strategic planning get out ahead of themselves by failing to get department heads – and their staff at all levels – collecting and using, i.e., learning from, performance data on a routine basis. Unless and until front line staff are using and learning from performance data, linking it to budgeting and strategic planning is virtually and exercise in futility. This isn’t a front line staff failure, but rather one of leadership and supervision, both essential elements of a robust performance measurement system. 
I believe this sort of message needs emphasis every time one responds to an inquiry like, “I am looking for municipalities currently using performance measures as part of their budget.” Didn’t many of us start with a similar “mission” from our City Manager and/or Board/Council? Without additional information, one can never tell what groundwork has already been laid in advance of endeavoring to develop and link metrics to budget discussions. Thus, the first response to such inquiries might best be something like, “It’s great to read that you’re interested in linking performance measurement to budgeting, can you tell me a little about the current state of your organization’s measurement system and how you’re using the data you’re collecting?” Advice can then stem from the response.

answers.author: John Garvison
answers.text:
We would all agree that the reason we want some sort of performance measurement is to tell our story. The key thing is how do we tell our story in a manner that our citizens understand it, and actually believe we are not using statistics or figures to paint the picture we actually want personally. That is what I consider the 'holy grail' of performance measurement or management.
For example, when I was the elected County Auditor in a small county in Washington State for nine years, I had numerous surveys from my customers (citizens for elections, document recording, vehicle licensing, finance) who complained about my having too many staff that were unresponsive to the customer needs. At first I disregarded these surveys as being a small minority, but then I took a closer look at my staff and saw there were staff that needed improvements some large some small. Well, I heard from the community that the cost of government was too high, I reduced my 11 staff to 9.5 staff, paid my existing staff more money and increased their training exponentially. This resulted in more cost effective service and my customer service surveys showed an increase in customer satisfaction.
However, the reduction in staff led to increase citizen outrage for those people who were not my everday customers, even though I had the performance metrics to back up my decision.
This is a case where I let my performance metrics drive my political decisions, and not the other way around. However, I can undrstand the rationale for doing it the other way around, and now that I answer to a 7 member elected board, I have an insight into the political world and political ramifications of decisions that they make. I think this with the use of performance metrics helps us have stronger decisions in the long run that we can get buy-in from interested stakeholders.
Tom, I see you are with Vancouver, I audited them in 2000 and 2001 when I was with the Washington state Auditor's office and Linda Gellings was the Finance Director there. I don't think we have met, but it was a fun audit to perform.

Tom, I see you are with Vancouver, I audited them in 2000 and 2001 when I was with the Washington state Auditor's office and Linda Gellings was the Finance Director there. I don't think we have met, but it was a fun audit to perform.

answers.text:
You touch on one of the least intuitive things we have discovered over time: How essential it is to not only improve and do things well, but to tell the community why you did it - i.e., in your case tell them you heard them say you were overstaffed and here is what you did in response....etc.  That seems to really earn traction in our community - I think because they want to know that we will sometimes do things in response to their stated needs.  Yes, I have been here since late 1999, and knew her.  - Tom
